awd_titl_txt: Topics in Nonlinear Functional Differential Equations and the Computation of Hausdorff Dimension
awd_abstract_narration:
This project proposes research concerning (a) the computation of the Hausdorff dimension of the invariant set for conformal, graph-directed iterated function systems, (b) Floquet multipliers for nonautonomous, linear functional differential equations and (c) smoothness questions (infinite differentiability versus real analyticity) for solutions of functional differential equations. Topic (a) is only loosely connected with topics (b) and (c); but a unifying theme in the study of all topics has been the use of the theory of positive operators and of generalizations of the Krein-Rutman theorem. For example, to an iterated function system as in (a), one associates a family of positive linear operators parametrized by positive real real numbers; and one proves that each such positive linear operator has a strictly positive eigenvector with a corresponding eigenvalue equal to the operator's spectral radius. The desired Hausdorff dimension is the unique value of the parameter for which the spectral radius of the operator equals one, and finding the Hausdorff dimension is facilitated by knowledge about the regularity of the eigenvectors.  In studying topic (c) one finds examples of linear, nonautonomous functional differential equations which naively appear to be real analytic. Nevertheless, such equations may have infinitely differentiable periodic solutions which fail to be real analytic at an uncountable set of points.  The theory of positive operators is helpful in constructing such examples.

Many real-world problems are best modeled by equations which take history into account, so-called "functional differential equations" (FDE's) or "differential-delay equations."  Thus red blood cell production in the human body at a given time involves knowledge of red blood cell levels six to ten days before and has been modeled by FDE's.  Modeling the pupil light reflex in the human eye again involves FDE's. Many other examples can be found, not only in biology and physiology, but also in population dynamics, mechanical engineering (mechanical vibrations), nonlinear optics (lasers with opto-electronic feedback), economics and physics ( the famous and little-understood two body problem of electrodynamics). It is likely that advances in the theoretical understanding of FDE's will eventually have real-world applications.  The search for such theoretical advances is a major focus of this proposal.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for NSF Award # 120138

 

This NSF project considered two topics: (a) smoothness of global solutions (i.e., solutions defined for all time t ) of differential-delay equations and (b) rigorous computation of the Hausdorff dimension of certain classes of fractal sets.

 

Differential-delay equations are generalizations of ordinary differential equations. They arise widely, e.g., in the modeling of biological phenomena like the production of red blood cells.  It is often easy to see that a global solution of a differential-delay equation is infinitely differentiable at every point t.  A much more subtle question is determining at what times t (if any) the global solution is analytic (as opposed to just being infinitely differentiable), the point being that analyticity has strong and useful consequences. In collaboration with Professor John Mallet-Paret at Brown University we give conditions which ensure that global solutions are analytic at every time t. However, we also find examples where the global solution is analytic on a nonempty open set but fails to be analytic on an uncountable closed set. Finally, we prove existence of global solutions which we suspect (but are currently unable to prove) are not analytic at any point t.

 

There are many objects arising in nature or mathematics which are so irregular or fractal that they can not be assigned an integer dimension. An old example of a fractal set is the famous Cantor set. A more modern example, inspired by questions about continued fractions, can be described as follows: Define J to be the set of non-negative reals. For  x in J define functions f(x)=1/(x+1) and g(x)=1/(x+2). Then there is a unique closed, nonempty set C contained in J such that C equals the union of f( C) and g( C). The set C is a fractal. It is more commonly described as the set of real numbers x in [0,1] which have an infinite continued fraction expansion in which only the numbers 1 and 2 appear. A hundred years ago the German mathematician F. Hausdorff realized that to each subset S of an n-dimensional Euclidean space one can assign a real number s which is greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to n.  The number s behaves like a generalized dimension and was subsequently called the Hausdorff dimension of S. It is known that the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set is ln(2)/ln(3), but in general there is no simple explicit formula for the Hausdorff dimension of a given set S. Results from this proposal, obtained in collaboration with Professor Richard Falk at Rutgers University, provide rigorous high order approximations, with explicit error bounds, for the Hausdorff dimension of various fractal sets, for example, many fractal sets arising in the study of continued fractions and complex continued fractions. In the particular example of the set C defined above we give an approximation of the Hausdorff dimension of C , with explicit error bounds, which is accurate to one hundred decimal places.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2022
Modified by: Roger D Nussbaum

Project Outcomes Report for NSF Award # 120138

 

This NSF project considered two topics: (a) smoothness of global solutions (i.e., solutions defined for all time t ) of differential-delay equations and (b) rigorous computation of the Hausdorff dimension of certain classes of fractal sets.

 

Differential-delay equations are generalizations of ordinary differential equations. They arise widely, e.g., in the modeling of biological phenomena like the production of red blood cells.  It is often easy to see that a global solution of a differential-delay equation is infinitely differentiable at every point t.  A much more subtle question is determining at what times t (if any) the global solution is analytic (as opposed to just being infinitely differentiable), the point being that analyticity has strong and useful consequences. In collaboration with Professor John Mallet-Paret at Brown University we give conditions which ensure that global solutions are analytic at every time t. However, we also find examples where the global solution is analytic on a nonempty open set but fails to be analytic on an uncountable closed set. Finally, we prove existence of global solutions which we suspect (but are currently unable to prove) are not analytic at any point t.

 

There are many objects arising in nature or mathematics which are so irregular or fractal that they can not be assigned an integer dimension. An old example of a fractal set is the famous Cantor set. A more modern example, inspired by questions about continued fractions, can be described as follows: Define J to be the set of non-negative reals. For  x in J define functions f(x)=1/(x+1) and g(x)=1/(x+2). Then there is a unique closed, nonempty set C contained in J such that C equals the union of f( C) and g( C). The set C is a fractal. It is more commonly described as the set of real numbers x in [0,1] which have an infinite continued fraction expansion in which only the numbers 1 and 2 appear. A hundred years ago the German mathematician F. Hausdorff realized that to each subset S of an n-dimensional Euclidean space one can assign a real number s which is greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to n.  The number s behaves like a generalized dimension and was subsequently called the Hausdorff dimension of S. It is known that the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set is ln(2)/ln(3), but in general there is no simple explicit formula for the Hausdorff dimension of a given set S. Results from this proposal, obtained in collaboration with Professor Richard Falk at Rutgers University, provide rigorous high order approximations, with explicit error bounds, for the Hausdorff dimension of various fractal sets, for example, many fractal sets arising in the study of continued fractions and complex continued fractions. In the particular example of the set C defined above we give an approximation of the Hausdorff dimension of C , with explicit error bounds, which is accurate to one hundred decimal places.
